section.name: brain
section.information: Here's some information about the topic: Coming to university can be a stressful and overwhelming experience, but don’t despair! Understanding your feelings and how to cope is the first step to feeling like you are back on track. First let’s understand what depression is and how it can make you feel: • Extended periods of sadness • A feeling of hopelessness, • Lack of motivation and self-belief. • Feeling of fatigue • Insomnia The severity of these feeling can vary between students. For some these symptoms can subside over time, however, it is always worth being aware of how you can cope and the advice you can seek.

• Maintain a positive attitude. Try replacing negative thought with positive ones. • Keep to a routine and plan your days. Having structure will make you feel more at ease. • Remember, you are not the only one who feels this way, you are not alone. Consider reaching out to those close to you such as family and friends. • Use our app to book an appointment with the Student wellbeing here at Newcastle University or contact them directly: 0191 208 3333.

section.name: heart
section.information: Anxiety often happens when we experience an uncomfortable, unusual or stressful situation. Physical feelings that may trigger included: sweating, an increase heart rate, an inability to breathe and panic attacks. Anxiety also affects us mentally due to the stain our bodies are put under. We may worry a lot, which resulting in a change of our behaviour towards others. We may feel overwhelmed and overcome by these feelings of anxiety and find ourselves acting out of character in situation. Also, some long term effects such may occur such as sleeping problems and depression. Situations where anxiety is common: 1- Day before the exam 2- Sitting in an exam room 3- Going away from home (e.g. studying abroad) 4- Going to a hospital Examples of what might causes of anxiety: 1- Past experiences 2- A drastic change 3- Genetics 4- New Experiences

Try to do some exercises to reduce stress for example such jogging, walking or swimming Stay relaxed by clearing your mind or listening to music, relaxation is one of the keys to this problem. Try to live a healthy lifestyle with a good diet Remember, you are not alone in this world sharing your problem with your friends and family also could also help you If you don't feel like the normal you after following some of the tips listed above, why not consider asking for help? Below are some places you can contact for a little extra help.
Breathe in and count to 2, These feelings will pass, Breathe out, Concentrate on your breathing

section.name: liver
section.information: Alcohol consumption for many students is a big part of university life, however it is important to remember the impact it can have on your health and studies! Excess consumption can have many consequences including the impairment of motor skills, harm to interpersonal relationships and along side badly affecting your studies. Peer pressure is often a large factor in student drinking and substance abuse, so remember it is okay to say no!
